headline: The Parable of the Washed Cross
description: A short parable about a small wooden cross, changed by washing, that becomes a symbol of how faith matures — rougher, truer, and weathered by life. It reflects on how God is sometimes felt as smooth and easy at first encounter, but becomes demanding, steadfast, and real in the long walk of belief.
author: Aleksandr Agnitio
whyItMatters: This parable captures the quiet endurance of faith beyond its first sweetness — the shift from smooth beginnings to rough, lived truth. It becomes an emblem of how Aleksandr frames God as not only peace but also demand, not only presence but also change.

motifMap.meaning: Faith altered by experience, stripped of polish but truer for it
Unexpected place where faith is rediscovered
The demand and reality of God’s way

articleExcerpt: And like my little cross, real faith in God is a little rougher when it is true — weathered by the washing of our old ways.
sourceFragments: I was given a small cross that was smooth and lacquered so one could rub their thumb along its length.
It was not the same cross. It had been changed. Gone was the smooth outside; left behind was something more bare, a little rougher.
And like my little cross, real faith in God is a little rougher when it is true — weathered by the washing of our old ways.
